content:
Categorizing by genre and number of players is a great way to organize your collection, and using stackable plastic bins with labels will make it easy to find the game you're looking for.

As for a new game to play with your cousins, I've got a few recommendations that are perfect for a family gathering:

1. **Ticket to Ride**: A popular train-themed game where players compete to build railroad routes across a map of North America. Easy to learn, but with enough depth for strategy. (2-5 players, 30-60 minutes)
2. **Sushi Go!**: A fast-paced card game where players pick and pass cards to collect sets of sushi dishes. Simple to learn, but with a good level of strategy. (2-5 players, 15-30 minutes)
3. **Qwirkle**: A tile-matching game where players try to create lines of matching colors and shapes. Easy to learn, but with a good level of challenge. (2-4 players, 30-45 minutes)
4. **Codenames: Pictures**: If your cousins enjoyed Scrabble, they might enjoy this word-guessing game with a twist. Players try to identify words based on one-word clues given by their teammate. (4-8 players, 30-45 minutes)
5. **Forbidden Island/Forbidden Desert**: A cooperative game where players work together to retrieve four treasures from an island/desert before it sinks/gets buried in sand. Exciting and challenging! (2-4 players, 20-30 minutes)

All of these games are great options for a family gathering, and they're easy to learn and teach. You can't go wrong with any of them!

Remember, the most important thing is to choose a game that you and your cousins will enjoy playing together. Have fun!
